title: What's a good processor speed for a laptop? - Quora

response.answer_text: It all depends on what you want the computer to do for you. For example: Lets say you just want to browse the web, watch Netflix, Hulu, create / print documents, pay bill etc then you can get an i3 / A6 (AMD) By the way don’t let people tell you AMD sucks compared to intel because for THIS type of use NO ONE will see a difference in performance. Literally. Regardless of what benchmarks say, it all depends on actual use. 4GB of RAM would be fine for this type of use. For casual gaming / light photo editing or heavy multi-tasking I wouldn’t go lower than an i5 or the AMD equivalent with at least 6GBs which would be pretty decent performance. If you’re video editing though, integrated graphics chips give slow rendering. Although if you’re patient then it really doesn’t matter. For example on my laptop there is an integrated intel 5500. Took about 10 minutes to do render an 8 minute video which… for me is a bit annoying. Hopefully you get the general idea. It’s not just about CPU speeds alone though. Different tasks require a combination of hardware. So for example if you’re using an i7 but only 4GB of ram with integrated graphics to play games, the performance for something like Call of Duty would suck. BUT if you have an i7 with 8GB and a dedicated graphics chip, the game would play A LOT better and you’d be able to have higher visual quality settings. But if you’re just doing general home use as I mentioned above, getting an i7 with 8GBs and a dedicated card would give you the SAME performance as an i3 with 4GB and an integrated graphics chip simply because you’re not using the computer in a way that would require that extra power. You could have a $3 thousand dollar Apple computer next to an i3 and if you’re just watching Netflix or surfing the web, you won’t see a difference. Hope this helps.

You’re not supposed to look at the speed so much anymore. That was in the past when performance was linear with speed. Now it’s much more complicated because there’s both single core and multi core performance, and laptops no longer have a single speed, they scale to a variety of speeds depending on requirements. For example my core i7–8550U is clocked at 1.80 Mhz which is much lower than even much older processors, but it has turbo of up to 4.00 Mhz, so the processor will dynamically adjust up to 4.00 Mhz when needed. It also has 4 cores and 8 threads which means this will perform much better in multi core tasks, then something with 2 cores, or even with 4 cores and 4 threads. To help you out, manufacturers group processors into categories, like entry-level (core i3), mid-range (core i5) and performance (core i7). I personally would never buy anything less than an mid-range, unless it’s a like a very compact PC for limited use. In the Intel line, anything below an i3, I wouldn’t even buy it for my grandma.

A good processor speed has nothing to do with the laptop being good overall. A laptop which has a i5 clocked at 3.4Ghz from the 4th generation is still faster than a i5 3.2Ghz from the 6th generation,in your context,but yet,when actual benchmarks start rising,the 6th gen wins. The reason why is because clock speed has now no longer become the deciding factor for how powerful a cpu is,and inthe general context of this question,the laptop. Architectual improvements,along with more efficient processing and new technologies being bolted on means that even if i bulky man who has been stuck locked up inside a gym for 10 years,would be beaten by a man in 5,if,and he will,use the new logic given to him. The concept is somewhat vague here,but if you can decipher it,good. Cause my brain is sleepy,and doesn't want to work. But anyways,for me,i'd at least get anything with a quad core and a minimum of 2.6GHz base. If it can turbo up to 3.6,then that's good.

A processor matters on the usage ,if you are a professional or a student you need a quad core processor with upto 4.00 ghz but if you are a hardcore gamer then you need a 6 or 8 core processor . a good processor speed is between 3.50 to 4.2 ghz. you can get a very good quad core processor like the i5 8th gen or the i7 8th gen for everyday use but if you want gaming all the time you can go for i5 9th gen, i7 9th gen or i9 9th gen which are either 4 or 6 cored. any intel processor other than the i series is completely useless. for example the oldest pentium or the core 2 duo. intel 10th gen processor are new launch with extreme ram speeds, processor clock speeds and the iris plus graphics. a processor is not measured by its speeds but by its benchmarks. this is why intel 10th gen processor with lowered clock speeds are better than the 8th gen high clock speeds because of its benchmarks. if you compare 2 or more processor then never compare them with their speeds, always with their benchmarks. if you are an amd lover then love the ryzen 3000 series and the ryzen 4000 series……

Use scenario? (Basic usage, gaming, compression, video editing, scientefic computing,..) There are number of other things that affect the CPU performance alongside the frequency. Number of cores and threads? CPU manufucturer? CPU architecture? Cache size? Also you do you need single core performance or your software can use any number of cores? Intel have better single core performance and lower power consumption than AMD, but AMD will give you more cores for less money. Since you have laptop, you need battery life. More cores = higher power consumption, higher frequency too.  For general usage, you may target newest architecture. Intel Core i3-5xxx (Broadwell) series is maybe what you want. Higher frequency between processors with same architecture and amount of core will give you better performance. Newer architecture will give you better performance than older with same frequency. How much it is between these architectures? Its very specific. Sometimes newer architecture can give you 10% more performance at same frequency, and sometimes its 50%. I cant give you more specific or better answer because you gave me almost no info.

The processor speed or rather clock speed of the concerned CPU often determines the laptop usage. For instance, if you prefer gaming notebooks or gadgets that can handle insane amounts of 3D modeling and rendering tasks, 3.5GHz-4.2GHz is a decent ballpark. For basic computing requirements, media consumption, and web surfing, 2.0GHz-3.2GHz is a good enough range. However, you need to understand that a CPU exhibits a base clock speed and even boosted clock speed in most cases, thereby allowing you to fulfill demanding tasks, as deemed necessary. Processor speeds declared with the Intel and AMD models often denote the single-core base speeds. Therefore, processor speed for a laptop also takes the number of CPU cores into consideration, as you must look at the single-core speeds and multi-core speeds in cohesion to evaluate performances.

It’s not just about ‘fast’ but also about electricity used, heat exchanged as electron movement etc. The acer predator is known for being the biggest beast in the laptop market. Depending on features, it can cost as much as $9,000 and weigh about 20 pounds.  Most other laptop manufacturers offer powerful laptops but it will cost you. Power per price will usually be higher though, in larger computer chassis meaning you’ll get more power for the price by purchasing a tower or desktop computer. Laptops are not really meant to be used for high performance and highly demanding applications. Core i9 processors are now being offered in some laptops, but there are different versions of the core i9 processor, and the most powerful versions of it will only be available in larger tower computers who are able to convert a larger electricity supply into performance and functionality. Here are the latest core i9 Alienware laptops from dell. Alienware Area 51m 17 Inch Gaming Laptop with NVIDIA GPU

Well, the i7-7500U i've had (for like more than 3 years) was perfect and i never complained. It had 2 cores and 4 threads of 2,90GHz and Turboboost of 3,50GHz. Never had any problems with it. I could do gaming, light editing with ease and speed. Don't get any 2 core CPU if it doesn't have any hyperthreading. For modern standards i would suggest at least 4 cores of Turbo clock speed of 3,4GHz, whether you have a laptop or PC, but i'm pretty sure there are other people here that can give you a more accurrate answer.

If you seriously need processing power, you're looking for something around an i7-5950HQ or similar. i7-4980HQs are also fairly common and obtainable in a large range of products.  The thing is... those CPUs belt out a lot of heat. That makes for thicker, heavier laptops, so even though they can deliver the best performance, they may not be the best purchases for you. If you're getting lost in the branding though, keep this heirarchy in mind (at least for Intel chips.) Celeron < Pentium < i3 < i5 < i7, and remember that i7s come in both dual core and quad core versions in the laptop world (quad core is generally more powerful... and more power hungry.) I don't recommend AMD chips for laptops unless you need a seriously budget device... and when we're talking about "best" unless it's "best on a restricted budget" AMD product is not part of the conversation.

My answer depends on how you explain “good”, and what kind of proccesors you are talking about. For cpu:Since you asked anything that runs above 3Ghz (maximum frequency ) is good for average use. If you are above average user, gamer or content creator you need to go for 4ghz and higher. Let me tell something other than you asked for,dont compare proccesors by their speed,though they are a big deal, there are other things you should consider. Newer generation proccesors are much more efficient so they can perform well at lower clocks. No of cores also matters, as softwares these days are optimised to work with multi cores. There are lot of other things when coming to a proccesor.

The “best” processor depends on your goals. For example I wanted a small light laptop that has a 8+ hour battery life before needing a recharge. I wanted it to take up almost no weight or space in a backpack and last all day with no power cord. The 1.8ghz i5 that Apple puts in their MacBook Air is perfect for this. My other laptop is an Alienware beast that is as heavy as a tank and sucks down power so fast the battery is dead in 30 minutes. This PC is running Linux and used for controlling and research on industrial robots. I need the big power hungry CPU and Nvidia GPU for processing sensor data (motor encoders, video camera, IMU,…) and motion planning in realtime. I think in general with notebook computers the reason you have them is for portability and you only need a big CPU if you have a specialized need. For most people battery life and light weight matter more so they should buy a MacBook Air. But on the other hand a few people are doing things like editing 4K video on location. If that is the case then you just can’t get enough power and you will have to put up with sort battery life and keep the power brick with you. I like to say there is no “best” but there is a “best match” to your needs

Processors in laptops have evolved phenomenally. Every laptop offered nowadays have great processors installed in them. Processors for the laptop are basically offered in four segments: Intel Core i3Intel Core i5Intel Core i7Intel Core i9Intel Core i3 is more for budget-oriented laptops as they are designed to handle normal tasks with ease. Best laptop with the capability to handle all tasks with ease like gaming, editing and many more are offered with Intel Core i5, as these are the best fit for the budget-oriented as well as performance. Both Intel Core i7 and i9 are designed for heavy-duty tasks such as video editing, gaming at 4k 60fps, photoshop, coral and much heavy-duty software. These are usually much costlier than their counterparts. Now depending on a user’s requirement, they can choose their required laptop with the desired processor according to needs.

When referring to a processor, there are many facts to be considered. Actually, people just check out the Hertz of a processor and chooses the one with the best. But, there’s more to be considered. Cache memory is the most important feature you’ve got to check before proceeding. L1,L2 cahces define the performance of the PC. Currently, processor manufacturing companies like AMD and Intel have focused to improve the cache memory. It doesn’t matter even if your processor possesses a speed of 2.0Ghz, but if the cache is more then it’s ok.

At present Intel Trumps the processor market at least in laptops. But in desktops they are getting kicked in nuts by the new and ryzen. Ryzen will probably have settled in laptop market by end of this year. They are busy making integrated GPUs and dedicated laptop GPUs. Coming to the question, the cheaper alternatives the core i3 7100 is satisfactory for all needs. but considerable performers are i5 7200 (very common), i5 7500 , 7600k. The high budget options are 7700k ,6700k, and 5820k . If you are thinking of getting a laptop ​with one of these, I would advise you to wait for ryzen powered laptops and I have been hearing great things about core i9 underway, so the competition will benefit us by reducing their prices and and thus we get the best money can buy. Hope I helped you, correct me if I am wrong.

What I tell people is if you get an i5 it should be fine. But as the other poster said, it varies. Actually the CPU is usually chosen for you. The best things to decide first are: What is the battery life you need (you should expect your runtime to be about 70% of what the manufacturer says the battery life is).What size/weight do you need.This will dictate the CPU, even between manufacturers. There may be 2 CPUs to choose from and one will be more expensive and will have higher performance. Here is an article. Which Laptop CPU is Right for You?

Define "good."  What are you running, how are you running it, and what is your goal?  For example, a 4 GHz processor is currently generally unusable in the mobile context: the heat and power consumption make them quite impractical.Processor clock frequency is weakly correlated to overall performance these days.  The architecture, memory system, drives, and many other things contribute to overall performance.  Again, the app one is running determines the right approximate balance.

Something quick with a small thermal footprint and low power requirements. A Gen 8 Intel core processor will fit the bill. It really doesn’t matter if it’s i3, i5 or i7. Go for which fits your budget. Of course the i7 will perform best, but the i3 will be more than adequate unless you have need of more power. The i5 sits nicely in the middle. The lower the TDP (Top Drawdown Power) the better as less power draw means longer battery life and less heat.

Well, I'd love to tell you, but there's no quantitative metric of processor speed. Different tasks will run at different speeds on different processors. Some tasks are designed for low-latency processors, others are designed for high-throughput processors. Different processor chipsets will favor different tasks. There's far too much to consider. The best way to determine the speed you need is to look at benchmarks relevant to the tasks you intend on doing with your processor.

As with most questions about what is “best,” that would hugely depend on what you intend to do with it. For some people, portability and battery longevity is their primary concern. In that case, a CPU like Intel Core m would be very good, but performance might be quite a concern. For some people, they love doing gaming on laptops, so in that case they should go for the fastest CPU they can afford, which is likely a Core i7 (and they should also go for the one with the best graphics chip they can afford!). My advice is to look at reviews in the internet about the laptop that you want to buy. They’re not 100% reliable but they should give you a better picture of what you might end up getting.

The best you could get would probably be an Intel Xeon. It's a CPU designed for a server, so it probably wouldn't run very well in a laptop. They're also very expensive.  What I'm saying is we have no idea what is best for you, since it depends on your needs and budget. Mostly budget. Also, GHz is not a great way to measure performance.

Processors today in general are really good. Anything new gen i5+ should definitely suffice. I'd recommend investing on the biggest bottleneck - Storage. In my opinion, SSDs have been a life-changer. Nowadays they're cheap too; but still expensive for a 1TB replacement. If possible, go for a hybrid approach; where 256GB on SSD for core applications; and 750GB+ of normal HDD for storage (should help meet your budget).

I generally no less than 2.0 GHz, and no less than 2 processors when running Windows due to virus scanning putting a high load on machines. This really does depend on if the laptop is being used as a desktop replacement and is on AC power 99+%, or if it being used portably frequently.

There is nothing like 'best'. It is a relative term. The processor that seems to be the 'best' today, will only be so till it is replaced by a better one. If one is best suitable for multitasking with too many cores, it may just drain your battery within an hour. So, it is good to go for something that suits your budget and requirement. If you are into programming and know exactly what your programs will need most, go to cpuBoss to compare and decide the 'best' processor for you.

If you want to swap out your CPU, you can’t. If you are buying a new laptop, do not get one with a U-series processor. U stands for “Ultra-low power. They are severely under powered and the “top of the line” 7500U , gets outperformed by the cheapest desktop i3. Also do not get a “Y” series processor because that stands for extremely low power. Get an “H” series(High performance graphics), an “HK” series (High performance graphics, unlocked), or an HQ series(High performance graphics, quad core).
honestly you cant go by that. It depends on the number of cores and threads as well. For instance and octa core 2.9ghz (i5 8400f) is WAY better than a quad core 3.2ghz (i5 4460)
